Award.AwardTitle: Invisible States and Double Conformational Capture in RNA-RNA Recognition: The Docking Transition of the Hairpin Ribozyme

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Ribonucleic acid (RNA) is most familiar as the messenger that carries genetic information stored in DNA to the sites where it is translated into the proteins that do the work of the cell. In recent years, however, scientists have realized that RNA molecules that do not encode proteins play a wide variety of roles in biology, and that many of these "noncoding RNAs" take up complex and intricate three-dimensional shapes in order to fill their biological function. In this project, the process by which the well-studied RNA enzyme known as the hairpin ribozyme forms its folded shape will be examined in detail. The results will uncover principles for the processes and driving forces of RNA folding that will be of general applicability to other noncoding RNA molecules and will thus enhance scientific understanding of a variety of fundamental cellular processes. In addition, a standard set of baseline technical parameters (NMR frequencies for atoms in RNA molecules that lack three-dimensional structure) will be generated that will be of use to many workers in the field of RNA biophysics. The lab in which this research will be performed has a strong history in the graduate education of underrepresented groups, and this project will continue and extend these efforts to the undergraduate level via coordination with existing recruitment and retention efforts at Michigan State.

Although the factors underlying secondary structure (helix formation) in DNA and RNA are relatively well understood, the detailed study of the driving forces and mechanisms of the formation of complex tertiary structures in nucleic acids has not kept pace with the great recent advances in RNA structural biology. The active conformation of the hairpin ribozyme is generated by an interaction between two RNA internal loops to generate an intricate docked structure with significant conformational rearrangements. It is hypothesized that this transition is an example of double conformational capture, in which both loops undergo fluctuations to conformation(s) resembling their docked forms and only collisions between loops that are each sampling those forms are productive for recognition. This hypothesis will be tested using NMR spin-relaxation studies of each loop in isolation. Such experiments can identify minor conformers, or "invisible states," sampled by each loop, and the hypothesis predicts that the chemical shifts of these invisible states will resemble those of the docked form. Recently- reported advanced chemical shift calculation methods will be used to estimate the chemical shift changes expected upon transition to a docked-like state. To rule out simple molecular unfolding, a systematic determination of the NMR chemical shifts characteristic of the unfolded state of RNA will be performed, thus producing a reference database likely to be broadly useful to workers in the field. Observed chemical shift changes to the invisible state(s) will be compared to those expected from both fluctuations to the docked-like conformation (as hypothesized) and to simple unfolded states. Finally, advanced molecular mechanics calculations will be used to map out the details of the free-energy landscape implied by the NMR experiments and to verify the existence of energetically accessible trajectories corresponding to the proposed pathways.

POR.DRECONTENT:
RNA that plays roles in cells other than the classic function of relaying information from DNA to the protein synthesis machinery is termed noncoding RNA. Recent decades have seen an explosion in the known biological functions of noncoding RNA, including in the regulation of gene expression and in technologies such as siRNAs and CRISPR, and the list of roles of noncoding RNA continues to grow. This has led to intense scientific interest in the structures and mechanisms by which RNA plays its varied roles in the cell. RNAs which act as enzymes, termed ribozymes, are an important component of these studies because of their intrinsic interest, because of potential biotechnological applications, and because their chemical activity provides a convenient means of assessing their function. We study a molecule known as the hairpin ribozyme which is found in the genomes of certain plant viruses. The hairpin is an excellent model system for many aspects of RNA biochemistry and biophysics because it is a relatively small, experimentally tractable motif that nevertheless reproduces many features of much larger and more complex noncoding RNAs.

In this project we examined the pathways by which the hairpin takes up its three-dimensional structure that allows enzyme function, i.e., its folding. The key step in this process is the interaction of two RNA loops to form an intricate tertiary (non-Watson-Crick) interface that involves substantial rearrangements of both loops. We showed earlier that this process takes place unusually slowly for a biomolecular interaction, but that the interface is extremely stable once formed. Our model is that, prior to the interface formation, each loop is highly dynamic and spends a few percent of its time in a structure resembling its form after interface formation. Only if two loops simultaneously in these competent states encounter each other will the interface be formed. We use a combination of NMR spectroscopy, which allows the assessment of the sampling of minor states of each loop; advanced computational biochemistry, which assesses the atomic-level details of the motions detected by NMR; and ribozyme functional assays of variants in which these motions are interrupted. The combination of these techniques is termed a “dynamics-function” study, and unambiguously demonstrates the importance of an internal structural rearrangement of a molecule for its cellular function.

So far, we have completed a dynamics-function cycle for the lead-dependent ribozyme, a smaller artificial system that served as a testbed for the technology. We have carefully characterized the biochemistry and biophysics of loop formation as a guide to experimental design, and have performed extensive NMR and computational analysis of one of the two loops in the hairpin. The data to date are strongly supportive of the model described above. As we continue to flesh out the model, the deeply detailed picture we obtain of the formation of a model RNA interface is likely to strengthen the understanding, and potentially to inform redesign for applications, of folding in a wide variety of other noncoding RNAs. This work has assisted in the training of numerous young scientists including a Ph.D. student who is now teaching Biochemistry at the historically-black Oakwood University in Alabama, and an African-American post-bachelor’s trainee who used his work in our group to strengthen his portfolio for graduate admissions, and will be beginning Ph.D. training at Michigan State in 2019.
